From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Dutch

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio:(file)
  • Rhymes: -eːlər

Adjective

[edit]

geler

  1. comparative degree of geel

Anagrams

[edit]
  • leger, regel

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old French geler, from Latin gelāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ʒə.le/, /ʒle/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (Canada (Shawinigan)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Toulouse)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France):(file)
  • Audio (France (Grenoble)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Hérault)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Massy)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)
  • Homophones: gelai, gelé, gelée, gelées, gelés, gelez

Verb

[edit]

geler

  1. (ambitransitive) to freeze
  2. (impersonal, weather) to be very cold

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb is conjugated like parler, except the -e- /ə/ of the second-to-last syllable becomes -è- /ɛ/ when the next vowel is a silent or schwa -e-, as in the third-person singular present indicative il gèle and the third-person singular future indicative il gèlera.

Conjugation of geler (see also Appendix:French verbs)

present participle or gerund1 simple gelant

1 The French gerund is usable only with the preposition en.
2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:
past historic → present perfect
past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

[edit]

  • dégeler

[edit]

[edit]
  • → German: gelieren

Anagrams

[edit]
  • grêle, grêlé, léger, règle, réglé

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Adjective

[edit]

geler

  1. comparative degree of gel
  2. inflection of gel:
    1. strong/mixed nominative masculine singular
    2. strong genitive/dative feminine singular
    3. strong genitive plural

Latin

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • (Classical Latin) IPA(key): [ˈɡɛ.ɫɛr]
  • (modern Italianate Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): [ˈd͡ʒɛː.ler]

Verb

[edit]

geler

  1. first-person singular present passive subjunctive of gelō

Old French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin gelāre.

Verb

[edit]

geler

  1. (ambitransitive) to freeze
  2. (intransitive or reflexive) to be very cold

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. The forms that would normally end in *-iels, *-ielt are modified to ieus, ieut. This verb has a stressed present stem giel distinct from the unstressed stem gel. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of geler (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive geler avoir gelé
gerund en gelant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle gelant
past participle gelé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il
simple
tenses 		present giel gieles giele gelons gelez gielent
imperfect geloie, geleie, geloe, geleve geloies, geleies, geloes, geleves geloit, geleit, gelot, geleve geliiens, geliens geliiez, geliez geloient, geleient, geloent, gelevent
preterite gelai gelas gela gelames gelastes gelerent
future gelerai geleras gelera gelerons geleroiz, gelereiz, gelerez geleront
conditional geleroie, gelereie geleroies, gelereies geleroit, gelereit geleriiens, geleriens geleriiez, geleriez geleroient, gelereient
compound
tenses 		present perfect present tense of avoir + past participle
pluperfect imperfect tense of avoir + past participle

Derived terms

[edit]
  • gelee

Descendants

[edit]
  • French: geler
  • Norman: g'ler, g'laïr (Guernsey)
  • Walloon: djaler
  • → Middle English: gelen, gellyn
    • English: geal
    • Scots: geal, jeel

Swedish

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

geler

  1. indefinite plural of gel
